citations.narrative:
On October 15th, 2022, an adult, male capuchin was exhibited at an outdoor fair in the Fresno, CA area and handled in a
manner which poses a risk of harm to the animal and to the public. The capuchin was allowed to sit upon the shoulders
and came in contact with the neck and head areas of members of the public including adults and children for photo
opportunities. Per the licensee, an experienced trainer handles this animal which is well-trained and controlled with a
neck collar and 5-foot leash. The licensee stated the leashed capuchin is approximately two feet away from the trainer
during these public interactions. It was noted that there were no incidents involving this animal reported at this event.
Allowing non-human primates including capuchins on the shoulders and near the head and neck areas of the public does
not assure the safety of the public or the animals. Members of the public may be bitten or scratched if the animals
unexpectedly are startled or become stressed. Additionally, the animals may become injured while placed in this position
and during an unexpected harmful or stressful event. During public exhibition, any animal must be handled so there is
minimal risk of harm to the animal and to the public, with sufficient distance and/or barriers between the animal and the
general viewing public so as to assure the safely of the animals and the public.
Correct from this time forward.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
